content:
There are no Constraints on the price itself. More than that, there are text that suggests the false constrain: "Each character is separated by a space". That kinda says that price can only be one character. And tests do not contradict that, only one validator does.

So you need to add a two-digit price to test 4. Until you do that puzzle is lowkey broken. Adding explicit constraints for the prices would be cool too.

Otherwise, very cool. Seems to have a perfect difficulty at least for js (I can't really speak for other languages).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Difficulty is ok, problem is simple enough for clash (could have been a Fastest mode as well)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This seems very suitable for code golf, a fairly simple problem but with lots of room to shorten with many tricks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice for shortest. Just a few suggestions (but I'm not 100% about these). 1) is that charCount really needed (at least in some languages)? 2) to me it would make more sense to have line 2 and line 3 swapped - first build a price list, then compute the total price (but again, not sure if this makes it harder/impossible for some languages). Great idea!
This seems like a pretty decent puzzle for clash of code, clear, simple, and suitable for shortest as well

This much more suitable as an Classic puzzle than a Clash.
Either way, good puzzle.

nice, I think it is an easy puzzle, but perfect for clash of code, also for reverse & shortest mode. 

I would change the input text for line to the following:
Line 1 : An integer charCount for the number of items in the shopping cart

This makes it more clear in my opinion.
____
below is a solution in Python that is even easier & faster than the solution given:

char_count = int(input())
string_cart_list = input()
item_price = list(input().split())

total=0

for i in string_cart_list:
    total+=int(item_price[item_price.index(i)+1])

1)I see no reason why length of line 3 depends on length of line 2. How about such test
4 2
aaaa
a 1 b 2 
---------
4
Of course we'll need to add another length to line 1 (not line length but list of possible items)

2) I also suggest remove trailing space from line 3 as it may be confusing (in case of previous change) or clearly write about it in statement (if you not change current constraints)
If you put the itemPrice first, there is no need to store stringCart, it would be useful for shortest mode.
I suggest to turn on fastest and reverse modes too
This is a relatively understandable problem, the solution isn't too hard to figure out.
Thanks for the comment. I will turn it on, unless more people advise to keep it to just golf.
Thanks for the comment. Does anybody else agree with this? I think having both makes it a bit more complicated and opens up the problem for more solutions.
Thanks, I updated the description. I intentionally wanted to do a non-golf style solution, but thanks anyways for the solution!

I don't think so. It took me less than 2 minutes to finish an unshortened working code. Of course, in Perl the input parsing is simple, while some languages may struggle with that, but still, this is way too easy for a puzzle.
Ah, commented before reading others comments. Yes, I agree with Andre.
